awd_titl_txt: Enhancing Preparation of Secondary Preservice Mathematics Teachers: Mathematical Reasoning and Proving as a Lens for Teaching
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will contribute to the National Science Foundation's goal of improving undergraduate STEM education to broaden and strengthen the U.S. STEM workforce. Preparation of mathematically literate and STEM-oriented majors begins prior to students reaching college. It begins with highly qualified and knowledgeable teachers, who inspire and prepare students to pursue STEM disciplines. Thus, it is imperative to prepare excellent mathematics teachers capable of enacting effective teaching practices in their classrooms. This project will address this teacher knowledge base through design, implementation, and study of a new, technologically rich capstone course called Mathematical Reasoning and Proving for Secondary Teachers. The course will enhance prospective secondary mathematics teachers' content and pedagogical knowledge to promote deep conceptual understanding, problem solving, reasoning, and proving skills. This emphasis concurs with the vision put forward by the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics and the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics. The successful implementation of this vision relies on a well-qualified and knowledgeable teacher workforce. The project will generate evidence-based approaches, instructional modules and facilitator guides to improve preparation of secondary mathematics teachers throughout the country, and by extension the project will enhance the mathematics education of thousands of middle school and secondary school students.

The innovative aspects of the capstone course Mathematical Reasoning and Proving for Secondary Teachers will include university-based experiences supported by virtual learning environments, a structured practical experience in local schools, and an emphasis on reasoning, justification, and proving as an overarching approach for teaching mathematics. The project will develop a concept model of the capstone course, four instructional modules, and the accompanying facilitator guides. The instructional modules will each address a critical topic related to proving, such as quantification, conditional statements, direct proof and proof by contrapositive. The project will utilize design-based research methodology to study how prospective teachers' content and pedagogical knowledge for teaching mathematical reasoning and proving develop throughout the course. The results will help to better understand the impact of the learning environment and its design components on enhancing prospective teachers' knowledge. Specifically, the project will contribute to the literature on mathematical reasoning and proving and the ways to incorporate them in teacher preparation and, consequently, in the mathematics classroom. The theoretical and the empirical knowledge generated by the project will be broadly disseminated to help to improve preparation of secondary mathematics teachers nationwide. The Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program will provide co-funding for this project in recognition of its alignment with the broader teacher preparation goals of the Noyce effort.

por.por_cntn:
Making reasoning and proving a reality in secondary mathematics classrooms requires that teachers have robust content and pedagogical knowledge of proof, knowledge of proof-related classroom practices and productive views of the nature of proof and of students as proving capabilities. This design-based research project Teacher Preparation in Reasoning and Proving (TPRP) developed an undergraduate cpastone course: Mathematical Reasoning and Proving for Secondary Teachers and studied how prospective secondary teachers’ (PSTs’) knowledge, dispositions and proof-related classroom practices evolved following PSTs’ participation in the course. The mathematical content of the course addresses proof-topics that are considered hard to learn and challenging to teach, such as, limitations of the use of examples in proving, argumentation structures, proof by contradiction and others. The pedagogical innovation of the course, developed by the TPRP project, is the Crystalize-Connect-Apply activity model. That is, the course activities help PSTs to crystalize their mathematical knowledge of proof, connect it to secondary curriculum by learning about students’ proof conceptions, and apply this knowledge by developing and teaching lessons that integrate the proof with school curriculum topics. Other instructional supports include technological advances such as the use of cartoon-based representations of teaching, the use of 360-degrees cameras by PSTs to video record their lessons, and video annotation tools for reflective analysis of PSTs’ own teaching.

To analyze the changes in PSTs’ learning throughout the course, the TPRT project developed a theoretical framework Mathematical Knowledge for Teaching Proof (MKT-P) and a questionnaire for its assessment. The project also developed a Dispositions towards Proof survey and other analytic tools for analyzing lesson plans, enacted lessons and learning from reflective noticing.

Thirty-five PSTs participated in the course over three years. The data analysis consistently showed significant growth of the PSTs’ MKT-P, proof-specific teaching practices, and improvement of dispositions towards proof at the secondary level. Over the duration of the project, the PSTs interacted with over 300 middle-school and high-school students, teaching them mathematics lessons focused on reasoning and proving in general mathematics, prealgebra, algebra, geometry, and statistics. The PSTs considered integration of proof in the traditional school curriculum’s lessons very challenging, but also worthwhile and relevant to their future teaching careers.

There are several barriers to integration of reasoning and proving in US classrooms, some having to do with individual teachers and others with institutional, cultural, and societal factors. Based on prior research of others and our own study, the project developed a framework: Teaching Mathematics via Reasoning and Proving (MTvRP). This framework contains three guiding principles: (1) Full curriculum integration, (2) Incremental and continuous emphasis on deductive reasoning, and (3) Adjustment of language, notation, and representations to students’ conceptual levels. Instructional activities developed in accordance with these principles have a potential to position reasoning and proving as vehicles for learning mathematical content, making these processes appealing and manageable for both teachers and students in secondary classrooms.

Intellectual Merit 

The intellectual merit of this study stems from its contribution to NSF’s mission of building a knowledge base that informs improvements in STEM teaching and learning, and the IUSE program goal to design and study innovative learning environments to enhance STEM learning and preparation of secondary mathematics teachers. The TPRP project addresses a timely and critical need to prepare highly qualified mathematics teachers with strong mathematical and pedagogical knowledge to promote deep understanding, problem solving, reasoning, and justification skills for all students. Through a rigorous research design and data analysis, the project demonstrated the effectiveness of the design of the course Mathematical Reasoning and Proving for Secondary Teachers for advancing content and pedagogical knowledge, as well as proof-related dispositions, and classroom practices of future secondary teachers. The project generated evidence-based and principle-based knowledge contributing to mathematics teacher preparation in the areas of reasoning and proving, teacher knowledge, and classroom practice beyond the context of this study.  

Broader Impacts

The project contributed to both undergraduate and precollege STEM education by generating evidence-based approaches for preparing highly qualified mathematics teachers capable of enacting effective teaching practices in their classrooms to help improve students’ mathematics achievement. The capstone course, Mathematical Reasoning and Proving for Secondary Teachers, became a permanent fixture in the undergraduate mathematics education program at the university of the study, continuing to benefit prospective teachers and their future students.

The project broadly disseminated the conceptual model of the course, curricular materials, conceptual and analytic frameworks, and research-based knowledge to the professional communities of researchers and practitioners. The study materials are freely accessible to the general public at: https://sites.google.com/view/pst-reasoning-and-proof/home, licensed Creative Commons Attribution-Non-Commercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-NC-SA 4.0) license https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/4.0/. The modular structure of the course allows other institutions to adopt individual modules or even individual activities.

The project also contributed to future workforce development by supporting mathematics education graduate and undergraduate students gaining research experience.
